title: How my sister died in Bauchi mining pit collapse — Brother
creator: Prima News
description: Mr Gayus Jonah Saraki, a teacher, tells TEMITOPE ADETUNJI how his sister, Beauty Joshua, died in a mining pit that collapsed in the Gudum Sayawa suburb of Bauchi metropolis, Bauchi State Can you share with us what happened to your sister? My name is Gayus Jonah Saraki. I am the elder brother of the deceased, [...]
content: Mr Gayus Jonah Saraki, a teacher, tells TEMITOPE ADETUNJI how his sister, Beauty Joshua, died in a mining pit that collapsed in the Gudum Sayawa suburb of Bauchi metropolis, Bauchi State Can you share with us what happened to your sister? My name is Gayus Jonah Saraki. I am the elder brother of the deceased, Beauty Joshua, from Bogoro, Bauchi State. She was one of the people who lost their lives in Bauchi State when a mining pit collapsed in the Gudum Sayawa suburb of the Bauchi metropolis. People in the villages visit the mining site daily to mine different minerals like precious stones and the rest. It is a major business the villagers engage in for survival. However, on that day, the cave collapsed and claimed the lives of some people, and my sister happened to be one of those people who died. They couldn’t escape the cave site when it collapsed. The incident happened on January 25, 2024, and she was buried on January 27, 2024. She was buried at the Christian cemetery in Bigi, Bauchi State. What did she do for a living before she started working at the mine site? After her secondary school education, we were considering if she could further her education. But in the interim, she wanted to live with our sister, who is a fashion designer, so that she could learn from her. So our plan was for her to start staying with our sister so she could learn fashion design from her. Unfortunately, she couldn’t make it because the mining incident took her life. She was staying in the family house where my parents were staying. She wasn’t doing anything that’s probably why she decided to also join those who go to the site for work. We were living together in the family house before I got my apartment and moved into it with my family (wife and kids). How old was she? She was 21 years old. How long has she been in the mining business? It hasn’t been long at all. She started working there a week before the incident. Can you narrate how the incident happened and how you were informed? I gathered that when she left home the day the incident happened, she had said that once she returned that day, she would not visit the mine again for work because her heart was not in that business. She said she wanted to learn fashion design. So it was quite unfortunate when I received a call when I got home about the accident. We were planning one of our brother’s burials when they called to inform me that our sister just had an accident. On receiving the call, I left my colleagues and the priest to check up on her. My thought was that I would go and take care of her, thinking maybe she just sustained an injury. But when I got there, I was shocked to see people just crying and wailing. They were telling me ‘See your sister’ and pointing in a direction. Then I turned and saw her lying on the floor and words failed me. My body was shaking. Some women she was working with were still inside the collapsed mine. People there were trying to look for a way to bring them out. Then I left my sister where she was lying to try to rescue the remaining women under the ground. We took my sister’s body and the other corpses to the hospital, and after that, we started making arrangements for how they would be buried. The incident was so devastating. What position was your sister in the family? She’s the number eight child in the family. I’m the firstborn. What do you do for a living? I’m a teacher. I’m 39 years old. I’m married with kids, and I live in Bauchi. How do they pay them in the mining industry? They pay according to what you get, and they pay by kilogrammes. When did she finish Secondary School? She finished secondary school last year. How are your parents and other family members coping with your sister’s death? Coping with the loss has been tough for all of us, including my parents. We’ve been trying to support each other through this difficult time, reminding ourselves of our faith and the belief that there’s something beyond this life. We’ve been telling our parents not to blame themselves or feel too down because we believe in something greater. She is in a better place. We’ve been finding comfort in our faith, reassuring ourselves that our loved one is in a better place and that there’s a reason for everything, even though it’s hard to understand sometimes. We believe that, in the end, there’s judgment and that those who have faith will have eternal life. These thoughts have been our source of strength and encouragement in this challenging period. As for my parents, they’ve been handling the situation as best as they can. They’re trying to stay strong and lean on their faith for support. We’ve been there for each other, talking and sharing memories of our loved ones. This has helped us feel a little bit better despite the sadness. It’s not easy, and there are moments when the pain feels overwhelming, but we’re taking it one day at a time and holding onto the hope and belief that we’ll be reunited one day. Can you describe the kind of personality your sister had? My sister was truly one-of-a-kind. She was a great character in so many ways. One thing that always stood out about her was how she handled corrections. She had this amazing ability to take feedback in her stride, never getting upset when corrected. Rather, she was always ready to embrace corrections and accept them as an opportunity to learn and grow. It’s something I’ve always admired about her because it showed just how mature and self-aware she was. Another thing about my sister was her aversion to idleness. She was never one to sit still for long. She always had a project to work on or a goal to pursue. Her work ethic was truly inspiring. Whether it was her studies or other endeavors, she approached everything with a determination and drive that was unmatched. She also had a kindness and compassion that touched everyone she met. She was always willing to lend a helping hand or a listening ear. Thinking about my sister, I’m reminded of just how lucky I am to have had her in my life. She wasn’t just a sister; she was a friend, a confidante, and a source of endless inspiration. She was truly unforgettable, and I’m grateful for every moment I got to spend with her. Have you received any communication from the mining company or the government officials after the incident? My father said the Ministry of Humanitarian called them and gave them cash of N40,000, but we haven’t heard anything from the mining company because my sister was not a full staff. What were your sister’s dreams before she died? She wanted to be a fashion designer. What are your thoughts on the need for safety in the mining industry? Ensuring safety in the mining industry requires proper regulation of the industry. Good supervision is essential, but it’s not enough on its own. We need to go further by implementing and enforcing thorough safety standards that address every aspect of mining operations. This means having clear guidelines in place for things like equipment maintenance, ventilation systems, and emergency response procedures. It’s not just about having these standards written down, they need to be actively enforced to ensure compliance. Regular inspections are crucial to make sure that mining companies are following these safety standards. Inspectors need to be well-trained and have the authority to take action if they find any violations. Training is also important. Miners need to know how to use equipment safely, how to recognise dangers, and what to do in case of an emergency. This training should be ongoing to keep everyone up to date on the latest safety procedures. And it’s not just about keeping miners safe. We also need to consider the environmental impact of mining operations. Regulations should be in place to minimise pollution and protect natural habitats. Overall, safety regulation and oversight in the mining industry need to be comprehensive and proactive. By implementing and enforcing strict safety standards, we can help prevent accidents and protect both workers and the environment. What are the things you would remember your sister for? I would remember her for her reliability in handling household matters during my travels. She was quite dependable on household matters. Knowing that she can be counted on to manage things smoothly in my absence undoubtedly brings a sense of reassurance and gives me peace of mind. Additionally, her willingness to take on responsibilities without complaint demonstrates her level of selflessness and maturity. Not everyone can handle tasks without protest, but her ability to do so reflects her understanding of the importance of cooperation within the family. I would also remember her visits to my home, particularly when she came to spend time with my wife and children. She was good at nurturing family relationships. These moments with her are cherished memories for all of us in the family. I would also remember her for her ability to understand and accept constructive corrections without arguments. This quality fosters healthy communication and strengthens the bonds of trust and respect between siblings. While not seeing her anymore may still feel surreal, the impact she has made on my life through her actions and presence is undoubtedly profound. From her support during travels to her emotional support and connection with my family, she leaves an indelible mark that transcends physical distance. It’s these qualities and memories that will continue to resonate and shape my thoughts about her, even though she is no more. What advice would you give to people dealing with the same loss or tragedy? My advice is that they should see the loss as God’s written plan for that person. They should accept that the person is being called to glory as there’s nothing they can do about it. Dealing with losing someone or facing a big problem can be hard. Everybody feels sad in their own way, and that’s okay. It’s alright to be upset, angry, or confused. It’s important to talk about how you feel with people you trust, like family or friends. Sometimes believing in something bigger can help. Some people find comfort in believing that there’s a plan for everything, even if it’s hard to understand. It is better to think that the person who passed away is now in a better place.

title: Charlise Mutten's mum returns to stand in partner's murder trial
creator: 9News
description: Justin Stein's trial continues in the NSW Supreme Court today with Kallista Mutten returning for a second day of testimony.
content: Tweet Facebook Mail Kallista Mutten could face claims that she shot her own daughter Charlise as she continues giving evidence in the murder trial of her former partner. Justin Stein's trial continues in the NSW Supreme Court today with Mutten returning for a second day of testimony. Stein, 33, has pleaded not guilty to murdering nine-year-old Charlise, claiming he witnessed Mutten shoot her own daughter. READ MORE: Massive rain system to soak 80 per cent of Australia this week ﻿ Charlise Mutten. (NSW Police) Charlise's body was found by police in a barrel by the Blue Mountains' Colo River on January 18, 2022 with gunshot wounds to her face and back. Following a full day of evidence on Monday, Mutten will now face cross-examination by Stein's lawyer, Carolyn Davenport SC. The court heard last week that following his arrest, Stein told a corrections officer he was traumatised after seeing Mutten shoot the girl. "I heard a shot and then I heard her screaming out for me. Then I ran back and she shot her again," Stein said, according to the officer. READ MORE: Ten people escape blaze in two-storey Sydney home overnight Kallista Mutten, mother of Charlise Mutten, will return to court today. (Dion Georgopoulos) Davenport told the jury during her opening address that it would become apparent Mutten, not Stein, had motive to kill the girl. At the time of her death, Charlise had been visiting her mother and Stein over the Christmas holidays from Tweed Heads, where she lived full-time with her grandparents. During the visit, the group spent their time between a Mount Wilson property owned by Stein's mother, and a caravan at the Riviera Ski Park about a 90-minute drive away. The trial heard earlier from neighbours of the Mount Wilson property who said they heard conversations regarding Charlise's parental custody which hinted at plans not to send her back to Queensland. READ MORE: Police appeal after woman 'gave birth' near Sydney river ﻿ Justin Stein has been charged with Charlise's murder. (Supplied) One neighbour had previously attended a dinner with his wife and mother-in-law where Stein, his mother, Charlise and her mother were also present. "(Stein) said that if anything happened and the child didn't go back to Queensland that he would end up in prison again," the neighbour said. During her evidence on Monday, Mutten told the trial she saw her daughter for the last time on January 11, when the nine-year-old travelled alone to spend the night with Stein at Mount Wilson while she remained at the caravan park. She said the following day Stein told her he left Charlise in the care of an auctioneer who was working at the Blue Mountains property where they were staying. Stein claimed Charlise had been vomiting and was too unwell to travel, and that she was in good hands because the woman was a mother of three and "practically a nurse", the court was told. Stein later said he believed the woman was not who she said she was and that Charlise may have taken by former associates from his criminal past. "I said, 'we should go to police'," Mutten told the court through tears. "He said, 'no, because if you ring the police they will kill her'." On January 13, while phone data tracked Stein allegedly travelling to three boat ramps across Sydney and eventually the exact location where Charlise's body was found, Mutten believed he was "going to war" to find her daughter, the court heard. "Justin said he's gonna go to war and go to places that he might think that she might be and go look for her and get her," Mutten said. Later, she said, "Justin had called me and said that he 'badly hurt' the man that was in the house (where) he thought Charlise was ... and stabbed him". When he returned in the early hours of the next day, Mutten says Stein told her, "It's not them, you can call the police in the morning". Mutten called police to report her daughter missing shortly after 8am the next morning. title: Portion of stage caves in during Rahul's rally in Bihar's Paliganj
description: Portion of stage caves in during Rahul's rally in Bihar's Paliganj
content: PALIGANJ (BIHAR): A portion of the stage partially caved in during the rally of Congress leader Rahul Gandhi in Bihar 's Paliganj on Monday. The incident took place when Rahul Gandhi was here for the Lok Sabha election campaign in the Patliputra parliamentary constituency, where Lalu Prasad Yadav's daughter Misa Bharti is contesting on the RJD ticket. In the picture, Rahul Gandhi was seen walking on the stage when the structure suddenly collapsed. While Misa Bharti was seen holding the hands of Rahul Gandhi.

title: ‘Ha’amini Yom Yavo,’ musical tribute to woman who embodied that spirit of a nation at war
description: "Ha’amini Yom Yavo," a musical at Habima National Theater, celebrates Yafa Yarkoni's life and legacy, exploring her rise to fame and enduring impact on Israeli culture.
content: The life of the graceful woman with a beautiful voice who embodied the spirit of a nation at war, is now explored at the Habima National Theater in the form of a musical. Written by Guy Maroz and directed by Eldar Groisman, Ha’amini Yom Yavo (Believe the Day Will Come) includes some of the best-known stars of the Hebrew stage. Elay Almani plays the role of Yarkoni as a young newlywed who rapidly became a sensational star in what was known at the time as “salon tunes.” Einat Sarouf shines in the role of the established Yarkoni, marking a time in her life when, thanks to lyrics written by Haim Gouri, Raphael Klatchkin, Naomi Shemer, and others, she attained a special place in the nation’s heart and international recognition. in the role of a mature artist faced with the fickle memory of her public, won longstanding ovations after this premiere. The musical begins with a hospital bed, where a medical doctor (Tal Mosseri) gently explains to Yarkoni’s daughter Rina (Lilian Barreto) that her mother (Almagor) suffers from Alzheimer’s disease. The stunned daughter must defend her mother’s reputation, face a crisis in her own marriage, and support a demanding older parent. Meanwhile, the audience is invited to take a trip down memory lane with Yarkoni as she looks back at a life that some would call a phenomenal success story. A clue to this narrative device can be appreciated when Almani sings a few lines from Habibi. Almagor is there watching her, tapping her finger on the glass as if she is creating the rhythm in her own mind, watching her younger self perform. For this musical, music director Lior Ronen crafted two impressive mini-shows, one sung by Almani and the other by Sarouf. Both performances are necessary and excellent pastiches – a condensed selection of Yarkoni’s most iconic songs, trimmed down to a few key lyrics, performed with heart and gusto during spectacular dance routines created by Tut Mullor. Set designer Adam Keller deserves praise for his precise, imaginative sets that take us from Tel Aviv’s bars to the Negev desert, with its warm tunes of reddish-yellow in the background, and then to the clinically cold hospital scenes with their unforgiving light. This works wonderfully well, partly due to the audience’s deep familiarity with Yarkoni’s music. The clear-cut thematic division seen on stage between an alleged Rebetiko-like period, when Yarkoni was a people’s diva, and a second period, when she was an Israeli Marlene Dietrich singing “Lili Marlene” to the boys at the front, should be taken with a grain of salt. On stage, a pipe-smoking Haim Gouri (Tal Kallai) hands her the lyrics to “Bab El Wad,” a song written to remember the fierce fighting at Sha’ar HaGai during the War of Independence. Yarkoni sings it and is rapidly transformed to the status of the nation’s “songstress of the war,” despite noting that “wars are terrible; only the songs are pretty.” Gouri, Yoram Kaniuk, and others served in the Palmach. They fought for a new country that they were also able to culturally shape at a level that today would seem impossible. A poet takes a drink, composes a poem, and then passes it on to a singer, who turns it into a timeless musical masterpiece that continues to play on the radio seven decades later. “There were times when we defended the outpost,” Hefer wrote in There Were Such Times, which is included in the musical. “Now on the outpost, a city was built.” When Yarkoni died, Kaniuk shared how she had come to perform for his Palmach battalion. Yarkoni sang “War is a Dream,” a tango written by Tolly Reviv. Then-Palmach Education Officer Benny Marshak had a fit. The tango, Rebetiko, and pop music were all salon tunes – “false Idols” to the ideologically driven older men who, like him, left Europe to create a Jewish homeland. Back then, female singers became the voice of a nation at war. Fairouz wrote and sang “Al Quds Al Atiqa” (Old Jerusalem) and Umm Kalthoum sang “I Now Have a Rifle” (written by Nizar Qabbani,) both of them Arab songs about the conflict. In a similar way, Yarkoni and Shoshana Damari reside in the collective Israeli soul. Klatchkin, who wrote the poem from which the title of this musical is taken, says that Israel’s wars are fought so that the day will come when we may “breathe and live.” The choice to have Almagor, known for her pro-peace views, play the role of Yarkoni, who was rebuked by the public over a possibly misunderstood radio interview in which she spoke out against the ongoing military control of the Gaza Strip, is an inspired one. In a pivotal scene, hecklers interrupt Yarkoni (Almagor) during her singing, questioning her loyalty to the state. This is a troubling but very sharp reminder of how fragile free speech is in a democracy still facing unyielding hostility.

title: ESPN announces major broadcasting change with special programming to honor NBA legend Bill Walton after his death
creator: Damian Burchardt
content: ESPN updated its Monday programming to honor the late NBA great, Bill Walton. The two-time NBA champion and 1978 MVP died at the age of 71 after a battle with cancer. Walton worked at ESPN for 22 years. He joined the network as an NBA analyst in 2002 before starting calling college basketball games in 2012. The broadcaster paid tribute to the former No. 1 overall pick with special programming on Monday afternoon. It celebrated Walton's memory on SportsCenter and NBA Today between 3-5 pm ET. ESPN also announced it would air the 30 for 30 documentary about the NBA legend's career and life – titled The Luckiest Guy in the World – on ESPN2 at 5 pm and 10:30 pm. "Bill Walton was a legendary player and a singular personality who genuinely cherished every experience throughout the journey of his extraordinary life," the network said in a statement . "Bill often described himself as 'the luckiest guy in the world,' but anyone who had the opportunity to interact with Bill was the lucky one. "He was a truly special, giving person who always made time for others. "Bill's one-of-a-kind spirit captivated and inspired audiences during his second career as a successful broadcaster. "We at ESPN extend our deepest condolences to Bill's loved ones, including the entire Walton family." NBA commissioner Adam Silver confirmed Walton's death early Monday afternoon. "Bill Walton was truly one of a kind," Silver said in a statement. "As a Hall of Fame player, he redefined the center position. "His unique skills made him a dominant force at UCLA and led to an NBA regular-season and Finals MVP, two NBA championships, and a spot on the NBA's 50th and 75th Anniversary Teams. "Bill then translated his infectious enthusiasm and love for the game to broadcasting, where he delivered insightful and colorful commentary which entertained generations of basketball fans. "As a cherished member of the NBA family for 50 years, Bill will be deeply missed by all those who came to know and love him." Walton spent 10 years in the NBA, playing for the Portland Trail Blazers , LA Clippers , and Boston Celtics . He helped the Blazers win their only NBA championship in 1977. The 6-foot-11 center won his second ring in 1986 to cap off his first season with the Celtics. Walton ventured into sports media in 1990, serving as a color commentator for CBS, NBC, and the local Clippers broadcast before joining ESPN.

title: House GOP Unsure Whether Calls To Hold Garland In Contempt Can Push Through
description: House GOP is unsure if they have the numbers to cite Johnson for contempt.
content: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS TIMES NEWSLETTER SIGNUP My account Log Out May 27, 5:48 PM EDT World U.S. Economy & Markets Companies Technology Digital Life Culture Sports Crypto Opinion NEWSLETTER My account Log Out US Edition World U.S. Economy & Markets Companies Technology Digital Life Culture Sports Crypto Opinion Listings & More Spotlight Glossary SMB Forum Glossary K-Wave CEO Spotlight Editions Australia Edition India Edition International Edition Singapore Edition United Kingdom United States NEWSLETTER Follow Us Editions Australia Edition India Edition International Edition Singapore Edition United Kingdom United States National House GOP Unsure Whether Calls To Hold Garland In Contempt Can Push Through By Ann Resuma Published 05/27/24 AT 5:48 PM EDT Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share on LinkedIn Share on Reddit Share on Flipboard Share on Pocket AFP Calls for a vote to cite Attorney General Merrick Garland in contempt of Congress remains uncertain since Republicans are still unsure whether they have the required number of votes to pass it. Two committees have passed resolutions to cite Garland in contempt. In addition, Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA) confidently stated that he expected the measure to pass "handily" the moment that members of Congress return from their short Memorial Day recess. However, The Hill reported that its source, who was well-aware of discussions behind-the-scenes, said that there were two Republican members who mentioned that they will not be voting for the said measure. The uncertainly whether a measure would pass lies on the small House GOP majority, which means that Republicans could only pass bills with just one or two defections from Democrats, assuming that the latter remains united in their votes. There is already a strong push from top GOP leaders for the Garland vote to be carried this week since there are already members who are saying that their colleagues are still not yet voting for the measure. Rep. Tim Burchett (R-TN) said that they will not be calling for a vote unless they know that they can pass it. He also noted that there is more than one GOP who have reservations on the measure. Another Republican, Dan Bishop, described the stance of other GOP members as being "squishy" on the issue. Johnson, on the other hand, referred to the non-passing of the vote during the previous week as a "calendar issue." Although delays are not necessarily uncommon, votes on such matters are often scheduled while lawmakers still have their momentum from their committees. Rep. Jamie Raskin (D-MD), of the House Oversight and Accountability Committee, said that the oversight meeting on May 15 was complicated and ended in chaos due to mentions of "fake eyelashes" used by Rep. Jasmine Crockette (D-TX). "I mean, the whole country was looking at Marjorie Taylor Greene talking about fake eyelashes, but nobody was focused at all on their outlandish claim that the Attorney General of the United States is in contempt of Congress," said Raskin. The GOP lawmakers wanted to cite Johnson in contempt after his refusal to turn over the audio recording of the interview of special counsel Robert Hur with President Joe Biden. The President has claimed executive privilege over the said audio recordings. However, lawmakers have already their transcript of the interview. title: Tech driving financial services contribution to GDP – Analysts
creator: Prima News
description: Analysts have identified technology adoption as one of the drivers of the growth in the contribution of the financial services sector to the country’s Gross Domestic Product. According to the National Bureau of Statistics, financial services were instrumental to the country’s economic growth in the first quarter of 2024. The NBS, in the Nigerian Gross [...]
content: Analysts have identified technology adoption as one of the drivers of the growth in the contribution of the financial services sector to the country’s Gross Domestic Product. According to the National Bureau of Statistics, financial services were instrumental to the country’s economic growth in the first quarter of 2024. The NBS, in the Nigerian Gross Domestic Product Report Q1, 2024 released on Friday, said that Nigeria’s gross domestic product grew by 2.98 per cent (year-on-year) in real terms in the first quarter of 2024. According to the bureau, the growth rate is higher than the 2.31 per cent recorded in the first quarter of 2023 and lower than the growth rate of 3.46 per cent in the fourth quarter of 2023. The performance of the GDP in the first quarter of 2024 was driven mainly by the services sector, which recorded a growth of 4.32 per cent and contributed 58.04 per cent to the aggregate GDP. A further breakdown of the GDP report indicated that the non-oil sector grew by 2.80 per cent in real terms during Q1 2024, driven mainly by financial and insurance, information and communication (telecommunications); agriculture (crop production); trade; and manufacturing (food, beverage, and tobacco). Highlighting the contribution of the financial institutions to the GDP, the report said, “The finance and insurance sector consists of the two subsectors, financial and insurance institutions, in which the former accounted for 93.19 per cent and the latter 6.81 per cent of the sector, respectively, in real terms in Q1 2024. As a whole, the sector grew at 42.18 per cent in nominal terms (year-on-year), with the growth rate of Financial Institutions at 44.41 per cent and 17.37 per cent growth rate recorded at 17.37 per cent. “The overall rate was higher than Q1 2023 by 19.81 per cent points, and higher by 9.89 per cent points than the preceding quarter. The quarter-on-quarter growth was 20.97 per cent. The sector’s contribution to the nominal GDP was 5.09 per cent in Q1 2024, higher than the 4.11 per cent it represented a year previous, and higher than the contribution of 3.76 per cent it made in the preceding quarter.” The Managing Director/Chief Economist at ADSR, Dr Afolabi Olowookere, told The PRIMANEWS, “The sector is growing, hence its contribution to the GDP will also grow. After COVID-19, the financial sector and ICT have been growing because people do a lot of transactions online. “Majorly, the financial sector benefited a lot from the depreciation of the currency. They contributed to the growth of the stock exchange. What they declared even in the last quarter in profitability is much. They did well and that spurs growth. So, when you grow more, your contribution would also grow because others are not growing as much.” According to an economist with the School of Management and Social Sciences, Pan-Atlantic University, Professor Bright Eregha, post-Covid, a lot of the sectors were not doing well except for ICT and the banking sector. “The reason is that these sectors are already integrated into the digital space for their businesses and if you check the contribution of ICT is increasing by the day. “One of the sectors that is making use of ICT is the banking and financial sector. For that reason, even when other sectors are not doing well because they are impacted by other things, the banking sector continues to grow,” he noted. Eregha, however, questioned the growth of the sector when the real sector in the country was struggling. “The second point I want to make which may seem contradictory is, that if the real sector is not doing well, one would have expected the financial sector not to do well because the assignment of the banking sector is financial intermediation. So, if the real sector is struggling conditioned on all the macroeconomic conditions that are affecting them; energy, subsidy removal, exchange rates and interest rate hikes, the real sector is impaired and not doing well, so what is the role of the banks and what is driving their growth? “If you check through 2020 till now, the real sector has not been doing well but the banking sector, which serves as an intermediation, is to get funds to where they are needed to spur the real sector. So, if they are making a profit but the real sector is not booming, then there is a question mark. If what is driving their growth is more of the non-interest-based assets against interest-based assets. If you look at the profits that they are declaring, you know that it is not tied to the real intermediation work that they should do,” he said. In a recent report titled ‘Digital Opportunities in African Businesses,’ the International Finance Corporation indicated that African firms could better leverage digital technologies to help their businesses become more productive and profitable. “Digitalisation presents investment opportunities for African firms and those who conduct business with them. Digital technologies are being adopted at a faster pace than previous waves of technological innovation. People and firms in Africa have embraced this transformation. “By making fuller use of digitalisation, African firms across all economic activities can become more productive, profitable, and integrated into global, regional, and local value chains,” it stated. According to the report, people can benefit from the lower costs and learning that digital technologies can facilitate. “Existing or new businesses can serve this rapidly expanding market—for example, by building digital infrastructure or providing appropriate software solutions,” part of the report read. Meanwhile, Afrinvest has maintained its 3.0 per cent GDP growth projection for Nigeria in 2024, saying, “This cautious stance is informed by the lingering impacts of ongoing reforms on growth potentials, challenging business environment, protracted security concerns, exchange rate volatility, dwindling agric sector growth (the minuscule growth in Q1 is the lowest since the negative print of 0.9 per cent in Q1:2023), and mounting risk in the external environment.” The International Monetary Fund projected Nigeria’s economy would grow at 3.3 per cent in 2024, as both oil and agriculture outputs are expected to improve with better security. NBS said that the contribution of finance and insurance to real GDP totalled 6.81 per cent, higher than the contribution of 5.35 per cent recorded in the first quarter of 2023 by 1.47 per cent, and higher than 4.95 per cent recorded in Q4 2023 by 1.86 per cent.

title: 7 movies you have got to watch before they leave Netflix in June
creator: Jacob Siegal
description: As excited as we are about all of the great new movies coming to Netflix this June, we’re sad to report that there are quite ...The post 7 movies you have got to watch before they leave Netflix in June appeared first on BGR.
content: As excited as we are about all of the great new movies , we’re sad to report that there are quite a few gems leaving the streaming service as well. With fewer licensed movies on the service in recent years, the list of departures has dwindled each month, but some months are worse than others, as is the case for June 2024. Several movies that have seemingly been on the streamer forever are finally getting removed in June, including , which is one of the most fun action movies of the past few years and features a great Brad Pitt performance. Speaking of action, we’re also losing , , and both of Tarantino’s masterful movies from Netflix. Best Netflix movies leaving in June 2024 Over the past decade, David Leitch has established himself as one of the best action directors in the industry. He followed up his 2021 Bob Odenkirk action thriller with , which stars Brad Pitt as an anxious former assassin tasked with retrieving a briefcase full of cash from a bullet train in Japan. Once aboard, he finds himself at odds with a host of other dangerous criminals. It’s a riot and a perfect lazy weekday movie. Years before Christopher Nolan turned a biopic into a near-billion-dollar box office behemoth, director Morten Tyldum and screenwriter Graham Moore adapted Andrew Hodges’s biography into a movie starring Benedict Cumberbatch. The movie explores how Turnig decrypted German intelligence messages for the British government during World War II, but it was dinged by critics for some historical inaccuracies. Sign up for the most interesting tech & entertainment news out there. By signing up, I agree to the and have reviewed the I could share choice quotes from the reviews of here, but do you really need to know anything other than that Jonas Taylor (Jason Statham) once again runs away from and occasionally battles giant sharks? I didn’t think so. Spike Lee’s legendary 2006 crime thriller follows Denzel Washington as Detective Keith Frazier, the NYPD hostage negotiator, attempts to defuse a hostage situation on Wall Street. Clive Owen plays the ringleader of the bank heist, Dalton Russell, Jodie Foster plays Manhattan power broker Madeleine White, and they’re joined by Christopher Plummer, Willem Dafoe, and Chiwetel Ejiofor. To this day, it’s Lee’s most successful theatrical release. I’m among the fans who believe Quentin Tarantino still hasn’t topped the duology twenty years later. These beloved movies are such a perfect mix of sweet, silly, and serious, with Uma Thurman keeping an otherwise unbelievable story of bloody revenge grounded so as not to let us forget that the Bride’s life is constantly in danger. Will Ferrell, John C. Reilly, Sacha Baron Cohen, Gary Cole, Michael Clarke Duncan, Leslie Bibb, Jane Lynch, and Amy Adams in one of the most ridiculous sports comedies you’ll ever see. Not all of Ferrell’s sports movies have worked, but some of us are . Because if you ain’t first, you’re last.

title: Alleged girlfriend, 26, of Las Vegas Raiders owner Mark Davis, 69, reveals she is pregnant
creator: Andrew Gamble
description: Las Vegas Raiders owner Mark Davis - who also owns the Las Vegas Aces - could be preparing to welcome a child after reported girlfriend Hayden Hopkins revealed her pregnancy
content: The alleged girlfriend of Las Vegas Raiders owner Mark Davis is pregnant - . Last month, Hayden Hopkins - who has been linked romantically with Davis for some time - took to social media to announce her pregnancy. On Instagram, Hopkins posted a black-and-white photo of herself on a beach with the caption ‘baby’ as she showcased her bump. While Hopkins' announcement did not disclose the identity of the father, the timing of the post led to speculation regarding her reported relationship with Davis. Hopkins and Davis went viral in 2022 when she was spotted with the owner in his suite at Allegiant Stadium. Hopkins certainly did not play down speculation of their relationship, sharing a photo from her premium seats along with the caption ‘Fun game’. When a fan asked about her experience in the owner’s box, Hopkins replied: "Haha MD [Mark Davis] is a legend! He’s my neighbor/friend." Even amid the four-decade age gap between them, rumors have persisted regarding their alleged romance. Hopkins established herself as a leading dancer in Las Vegas, captivating audiences while claiming various awards and performing alongside premier artists like Jason Derulo. Hopkins’ career took her from Seattle to the bright lights of Las Vegas, journeying from winning dance titles as a teenager and gracing the covers of leading dance magazines. Her talent has been clear throughout her rise, while she recently starred as "La Belle" in Cirque du Soleil's "Mystere" show in Sin City. Hopkins is also an Instagram model amassing more than 216k followers as she often posts photos by the beach where she showcases her remarkable physique. Before her Vegas residency, the 26-year-old traveled across the United States, Canada, and Australia to teach, choreograph, and perform various routines. Davis has not directly addressed the relationship nor the pregnancy rumors himself publicly. Since assuming control of the Raiders franchise after his father Al passed away in 2011, the 69-year-old has kept his personal life out of the public eye. If the rumors are accurate, it seems another member will be added to the Raiders family. Davis, who engineered the Raiders' sensational move from Oakland to Las Vegas as the franchise chases a first Super Bowl title since the days of head coach Tom Flores, is also the owner of the back-to-back champion .

title: Homeowner shocked to see ‘meteorite’ scorch through sky and plummet next to his property
creator: Paul Sims
content: A HOMEOWNER has told of his shock after watching a suspected meteorite scorch through the sky and impact next to his property. Dan Charlton was in his back garden in the early hours when he saw a green light and heard a “whoosh” as the object plummeted to earth. He said: “I went outside and looked up and saw this light and thought, ‘Is that a firework?’ “It was really close. "It came down in a straight line and what was interesting was it had a green flame, like a hue, that burnt and then disappeared. “You could hear it make a brief ‘whoosh’ sound and then I was expecting a big bang but it was just silent. “There was no one else around and I thought ‘that’s definitely a meteorite’. “I was fascinated. If I had my camera I could’ve caught the last second. That would’ve been awesome.” The next day, he found a small charred rock lying in a street nearby. A geologist saw a picture and said it “appears to be a meteorite”. Dan, from Wakefield, West Yorks , took the rock to the University of Leeds where he met Professor Simon Kelley from the School of Earth and Environment. Professor Kelley said it was too early to tell if the rock is a meteorite but is carrying out further testing.
